title: 109_s3895
content: The "Sacramento River National Recreation Area Act of 2006" establishes the Sacramento River National Recreation Area, with definitions for terms like management plan, Recreation Area, Secretary, and State. The Sacramento River National Recreation Area is established in California to conserve riparian and associated areas managed by the Redding Field Office. It consists of approximately 17,000 acres adjacent to the Sacramento River, lower Battle Creek, and lower Paynes Creek. A map depicting the boundaries was created in May 2002. After 3 years, the Secretary must submit a map and legal description of the Recreation Area to the Senate and House Committees. The submitted map and description will have the same legal force as the Act, with the Secretary allowed to correct errors. Copies of the map will be available for public inspection at the Bureau of Land Management offices. The Recreation Area map and legal description must be submitted to the Senate and House Committees after 3 years, with copies available for public inspection at the Bureau of Land Management office in California. SEC. 4. MANAGEMENT. The Secretary must manage the Recreation Area to conserve, protect, and enhance its resources and values in accordance with relevant laws. Within 3 years of this Act, a comprehensive long-range management plan must be submitted to the Senate and House Committees on Energy and Natural Resources and Resources, respectively. The management plan for the Recreation Area must describe appropriate uses and management in consultation with relevant agencies. It may incorporate decisions from previous plans and wildlife habitat management plans. The Recreation Area management plan must consult with relevant agencies, adjacent landowners, and stakeholders. Federal land within the area is withdrawn from various activities under public land and mining laws. Hunting and fishing are allowed in accordance with applicable regulations. The Recreation Area allows fishing in accordance with Federal and State laws. Motorized vehicles are limited to established roadways. Motorized boats on the Sacramento River are not restricted, with local authorities regulating for safety. Grazing of livestock may continue on public land within the Recreation Area. The Secretary may acquire land within the Recreation Area through donation, transfer, purchase, or exchange, with the owner's consent, subject to regulations and laws. Authorization of appropriations for carrying out the Act.
